title: 105_hr3894
content: The Act may be cited as the "Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act". The Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act emphasizes the importance of scientific research and technology development in maintaining air, space, and information superiority. It highlights the historical significance of investing in Air Force research and development, which has benefited American industry and the economy. The Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act emphasizes the importance of scientific research and technology development in maintaining air, space, and information superiority. SEC. 3. SENSE OF CONGRESS REGARDING SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY FUNCTIONS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF THE AIR FORCE. The Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act highlights the need for dedicated funding for emerging technologies and new technology areas. It emphasizes the separation of management and funding for science and technology from acquisition. Additionally, it calls for increasing investments in critical information technology programs and maintaining a strong base of scientists and engineers with technical expertise. The Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act aims to enhance technical education for Air Force officers and civilian employees. It proposes increasing the number of technical degrees at the master's level and eliminating 5 percent of science and technology programs annually to fund new initiatives. The Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act proposes amendments to enhance technical education within the Department of the Air Force. The Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act proposes amendments to separate research and development functions from equipping functions within the Department of the Air Force. This includes establishing a new Research and Development function and an Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Science and Technology. The Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act proposes amendments to establish key positions like the Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Science and Technology and the Deputy Chief of Staff for Science and Technology. This includes renumbering Assistant Secretaries and Deputy Chiefs of Staff to accommodate these new roles. SEC. 5. STUDY. The Secretary of the Air Force is required to contract the National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences to study the technology base of the Air Force. The study will recommend minimum requirements to maintain a technology base for superiority in air and space weapons systems, address effects on national defense and industries by reducing funding, and recommend appropriate staff levels. A report must be submitted within 120 days of completing the study. The Secretary of the Air Force must contract the National Research Council to study the technology base of the Air Force and recommend minimum requirements to maintain superiority in air and space weapons systems. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within 120 days.
